articles.headline: Marketing Budgets Rise for Some Giants
articles.snippet: At several major companies, the outlook for ad spending is even sunnier than earlier forecast.
articles.abstract: At several major companies, the outlook for ad spending is even sunnier than earlier forecast.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last couple of months, forecasters have been predicting that 2012 would be a better year for Madison Avenue and media companies as more marketers increased advertising budgets. That outlook is starting to brighten further as some of the biggest spenders reveal plans to open their wallets even wider than had been expected.

articles.headline: Some Doubt a Settlement Will End Mortgage Ills
articles.snippet: Housing advocates are skeptical that new rules will provide underwater borrowers with a single point of contact to help them navigate the mortgage maze.
articles.abstract: Housing advocates are skeptical that new rules will provide underwater borrowers with a single point of contact to help them navigate the mortgage maze.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as government officials prepare to unveil new standards this week for how banks treat millions of Americans facing foreclosure, housing advocates and homeowners are skeptical the rules will be able to do something past efforts have not: provide a beleaguered borrower with one individual to help them navigate the mortgage maze.

articles.headline: Poland Leads Wave of Communist-Era Reckoning
articles.snippet: After decades of resisting, Poland and many of its neighbors in Central and Eastern Europe have decided the time is right to deal with their Communist past.
articles.abstract: After decades of resisting, Poland and many of its neighbors in Central and Eastern Europe have decided the time is right to deal with their Communist past.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — For all that Poland has accomplished since the fall of the Iron Curtain, it has long resisted fully coming to terms with its Communist past — the oppression, the spying, even the massacres. Society preferred to forget, to move on.

articles.headline: Trademarks Take On New Importance in Internet Era
articles.snippet: A legal battle over Pretzel Crisps underscores the value of a brand name.
articles.abstract: A legal battle over Pretzel Crisps underscores the value of a brand name.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — As a serial snack-food entrepreneur, Warren Wilson is no stranger to the challenges of running a business.

articles.headline: Catholic Hospitals Expand, Religious Strings Attached
articles.snippet: Some financially strong Catholic-sponsored medical centers are joining with smaller secular hospitals, in some cases limiting access to treatments like contraception and abortion.
articles.abstract: Some financially strong Catholic-sponsored medical centers are joining with smaller secular hospitals, in some cases limiting access to treatments like contraception and abortion.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Roman Catholic leaders and government officials clash over the proper role of religion and reproductive health, shifts in health care economics are magnifying the tension. Financially stronger Catholic-sponsored medical centers are increasingly joining with smaller secular hospitals, in some cases limiting access to treatments like contraception, abortion and sterilization.

articles.headline: Europe Agrees on New Bailout to Help Greece Avoid Default
articles.snippet: After more than 12 hours of talks, euro zone finance ministers approved a new bailout of 130 billion euros, or $172 billion, under which private investors in Greek debt will take steep losses to help stave off a default.
articles.abstract: After more than 12 hours of talks, euro zone finance ministers approved a new bailout of 130 billion euros, or $172 billion, under which private investors in Greek debt will take steep losses to help stave off a default.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Greece finally secured its second giant bailout early Tuesday after euro zone finance ministers agreed to save it from bankruptcy in exchange for severe austerity measures and strict conditions.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Campaigns Grow More Dependent on ‘Super PAC’ Aid
articles.snippet: Intense campaigning in the early-nominating states has left the leading Republican presidential candidates increasingly reliant on millions spent on their behalf by outside groups.
articles.abstract: Intense campaigning in the early-nominating states has left the leading Republican presidential candidates increasingly reliant on millions spent on their behalf by outside groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: Weeks of intense campaigning in the early nominating states have left the leading Republican presidential candidates increasingly dependent on millions of dollars spent on their behalf by outside “super PACs,” reports filed with the Federal Election Commission on Monday showed.

articles.headline: Online Data Helping Campaigns Customize Ads
articles.snippet: Some Republican candidates are said to be using microtargeting, a sophisticated technology that allows campaigns to tailor messages to specific voters.
articles.abstract: Some Republican candidates are said to be using microtargeting, a sophisticated technology that allows campaigns to tailor messages to specific voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Political campaigns, which have borrowed tricks from Madison Avenue for decades, are now fully engaged on the latest technological frontier in advertising: aiming specific ads at potential supporters based on where they live, the Web sites they visit and their voting records.

articles.headline: Taser’s Latest Police Weapon: The Tiny Camera and the Cloud
articles.snippet: A new camera that clips to a collar or sunglasses can record two hours of video, which could provide evidence in controversies over police officers’ use of force.
articles.abstract: A new camera that clips to a collar or sunglasses can record two hours of video, which could provide evidence in controversies over police officers’ use of force.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Sgt. Brandon Davis vividly recalled the moment before he killed Eric Wayne Berry, but it was not the way it really happened.

articles.headline: Koran Burning in NATO Error Incites Afghans
articles.snippet: The NATO commander in Afghanistan issued a fervent apology on Tuesday for foreign troops having “improperly disposed” of Korans and Islamic materials.
articles.abstract: The NATO commander in Afghanistan issued a fervent apology on Tuesday for foreign troops having “improperly disposed” of Korans and Islamic materials.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGRAM, Afghanistan — Word that NATO personnel had burned an undisclosed number of Korans and were preparing to dispose of many more by incineration set off an angry protest here on Tuesday. NATO officials rushed to apologize publicly and profusely, trying to head off what they feared could be a nationwide outburst of violence as news of the burning was gradually broadcast across the country.
articles.byline: By Sangar Rahimi and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: New Bailout Is a Reprieve for Greece, but Doubts Persist
articles.snippet: Longer-term doubts over Greece's ability to repay its staggering debts remain, raising questions about whether even more rescue money will eventually be needed.
articles.abstract: Longer-term doubts over Greece's ability to repay its staggering debts remain, raising questions about whether even more rescue money will eventually be needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Greece may have dodged a default with its last-minute bailout deal, but longer-term doubts over its ability to repay its staggering debts remain, raising questions about whether even more rescue money will eventually be needed.

articles.headline: Justices Take Up Race as a Factor in College Entry
articles.snippet: The court’s decision in a new case has the potential to undo an accommodation on affirmative action in higher education reached by the court in 2003.
articles.abstract: The court’s decision in a new case has the potential to undo an accommodation on affirmative action in higher education reached by the court in 2003.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a 2003 decision that the majority said it expected would last for 25 years, the Supreme Court allowed public colleges and universities to take account of race in admission decisions. On Tuesday, the court signaled that it might end such affirmative action much sooner than that.
